citation.article-title: Analysis of 16S rRNA and methane monooxygenase gene sequences reveals a novel group of thermotolerant and thermophilic methanotrophs, Methylocaldum gen. nov.

p.s: Methylocaldum (Me.thy.lo.cal.dum. (methylo N.L.n. the methyl radical; caldus L. adj. hot; Methylocaldum M.L.n., heat-loving methylotroph)
Cells are gram-negative and may vary in shape from coccoidal to long rods.
Moderate thermophiles that grow at temperatures exceeding 40°C.
G+C content varies from 57 to 59 mol%.
Methane can be used as sole source of carbon and energy.
They do not grow on compounds containing carbon-carbon bonds.
They possess key enzymes for both the ribulose monophosphate and the serine pathways of formaldehyde assimilation.
Soluble methane monooxygenase is not present.
Natural habitats are: soil, hot springs.
The type species of the genus is Methylocaldum szegediense.
It has been deposited in the NCIMB.
